column5: Im dont know if this is the right place to post this or not, but I'm trying to find some 3 or 4 inch twister tails that have a chartruese body and red tail. I like to use them both in Canada and in Kansas. I bought a 100 a couple of years ago but Im just about out. Those canada rocks seem to eat them. Any way I have looked and looked and I have not been able to find any. Im in hopes that someone here might now of some place that I can get some. Thanks

I think you might be talking about a product called " Munchies." (chartruse body with red or pink tail) They were distributed by Lindy/Little Joe. I think they may be hard to get or discontinued. I too have used them effectively in Canada. Maybe others can help more.
You might try chartruese and a red dye pen. Would be a lot of work.
Red dip would be quicker than a pen, but still messy. Spike-it is one brand (of many) that has both dip and pens.

Don't know if any of these are getting close to what you're looking for. . . Cabelas has one that's a bubblegum body and chartreuse tail. See http://www.cabelas.com/product/Fishing/Soft-Baits/Grubs|/pc/104793480/c/104772780/sc/104365980/Cabelas-Action-Tail8482-Grubs-150-Per-25/739795.uts?destination=%2Fcatalog%2Fbrowse%2Ffishi ng-soft-baits-grubs%2F_%2FN-1100337&WTz_l=SEO%3Bcat104365980They also have a triple tail grub with chartreuse body and pink tail. Seehttp://www.cabelas.com/catalog/produ...AL%3BIK-113615AGM Products has this one - http://www.agmdiscountfishing.co.uk/...cs-p-2843.html - but they're in the UK. Don't know if anyone in the U.S. carries them.

BFISHNTACKLE.com. We had great luck using their line of rubber tails. The MOXIES really worked well on the eyes up North.Great assortment of sizes and colors.Their jigheads are also very nice.Paint free eyes and paint that does not chip off.

Thanks for the info. I thought I had found a 100 but when the guy checked they had been sold. So Im still looking. Why has red gotten so hard to find? If I cant find any I have never tried dye but I may have to.
You may not want to dip too many at one time. My luck with dipping has been the the dip color eventually takes over the whole lure. Bill Krejca
